Award.AwardTitle: Development of an Integrated View of Plasma Instability Processes in the Lower Ionosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
Earth's ionosphere is a mixture of neutral gas and charged particles. The ionosphere is generally broken out by layers, defined according to the wavelengths of the radiation most commonly absorbed. The E-region extends from 90-150 km and is ionized through X-ray and ultraviolet radiation. The F-region (150-600 km) is ionized by extreme ultraviolet radiation. Although waves and disturbances ("structuring") occur throughout the ionospheric medium ("plasma"), studies often focus on; either the E or F layer owing in part to limitations of experimental and theoretical; techniques employed. As a result, development of a unified view of ionospheric plasma structuring processes remains incomplete. This proposal will fill this gap by (1) developing a unified plasma instability theory applicable in the broad range of altitudes including the previously unexplored transitional valley region between the E and F region peaks and (2) observing the valley region with a radar that routinely receives returns from a broad range of altitudes. The proposed research leverages NSF assets and knowledge synthesis to contribute fundamentally to the theory of plasma instability and structuring. This knowledge is relevant to the communication and navigation industries, and therefore to society. The integrated theory will be incorporated into UAF plasma physics classes, that currently rely primarily on original journal publications rather than teaching modules. The proposal will also fund a new Ph.D. student.

The proposed research will address the fundamental question of what combination of destabilizing and stabilizing factors results in the plasma perturbations growing in amplitude and producing ionospheric structures. The actual proposal activity consists of three interconnected projects: 1. Development a unified theory of ionospheric plasma instabilities including thermal, inertial, and gradient effects for arbitrary altitude and propagation; 2. Determination of the critical gradient length required to destabilize plasma in the non-isothermal case for arbitrary altitude; 3. Analysis of SuperDARN and ISR data to investigate small-scale irregularity occurrence in the previously unexplored transitional "valley" region (~150 km). These measurements are expected to provide support for a theory that strong gradients are required to make plasma unstable in the valley at small scales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the work supported by this award is associated with the development of the fluid theory of the fundamental plasma instabilities in the Earth?s ionosphere including its E region (near 110 km in altitude) and F region (above 150 km). These instabilities are responsible for formation of plasma density irregularities or structures. These plasma density structures are important since they represent a major source of degradation of radio communication signals, e.g. radio transmissions from navigation satellites and radar surveillance. The major outcome is unification of plasma instability theories across different altitudinal layers, scales, and propagation regimes. Whereas previous studies focused on specific instabilities in specific ionospheric domains, the current effort focused on development of the unified theory that integrated different instabilities across multiple ionospheric layers, including the E and F regions and the transitional "valley"' region between them.

The research results have been reported in 4 refereed journal publications and 2 international conference papers. Below some of the highlights of the research conducted are described.

A theoretical study has been undertaken focusing on generalization (for arbitrary altitude) of the standard expressions describing the fundamental plasma instability processes that lead to formation of plasma structures [Makarevich, 2019a]. It has been discovered that the fundamental two-stream plasma instability does not necessarily require demagnetized ions and can be driven by the ion inertia in the region which previously was considered to be stable to the instability [Makarevich, 2019b]. A unified fluid theory of ionospheric electrostatic instabilities was developed that included thermal effects due to non-isothermal processes for arbitrary ion magnetization, background density, gradient, and wave propagation [Makarevich, 2020]. Analytic analysis of the ionospheric instability behavior was conducted that highlighted usefulness of an analytic treatment for revealing additional insights into the plasma processes that may remain hidden using only numerical treatment [Makarevich, 2021].

Broader Impacts: PI Makarevich has taught a lecture series entitled ?Space Weather, Northern Lights, and Their Impacts on Space Technology? at the Osher Lifelong Learning Institute (OLLI) at the Denver University. OLLI students are adult learners, age 50 and "better" and, through this activity, the PI has contributed to improving public literacy.  

 

References:

  1. Makarevich, R. A., Toward an integrated view of ionospheric plasma instabilities: 3. Explicit growth rate and oscillation frequency for arbitrary altitude, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 124, 6138?6155, doi:10.1029/2019JA026584, 2019a.
  2. Makarevich, R. A., Toward an integrated view of ionospheric plasma instabilities: 4. Behavior in the transitional valley region, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 124, 9709?9724, doi:10.1029/ 2019JA027303, 2019b.
  3. Makarevich, R. A., Toward an integrated view of ionospheric plasma instabilities: 5. Ion-thermal instability for arbitrary ion magnetization, density gradient, and wave propagation, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 125, doi:10.1029/2020JA028349, 2020.
  4. Makarevich, R. A., Toward an integrated view of ionospheric plasma instabilities: 6. Analytic analysis of thermal effects, J. Geophys. Res. Space Physics, 126, doi:10.1029/2021JA029178, submitted, 2021.
